articles.headline: Weary of War, but Favoring Airstrike Plan
articles.snippet: Many Americans agree that ISIS is a threat to the United States, but many wonder whether the country should edge toward another war.
articles.abstract: Many Americans agree that ISIS is a threat to the United States, but many wonder whether the country should edge toward another war.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — A few months ago, Kevin Kinard, a 55-year-old utility worker here, had barely heard of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. But when the Sunni militant group beheaded a second American journalist, Mr. Kinard clicked on an Internet video of the execution — and lost sleep for two nights.

articles.headline: Jobless Rate May Be a Flawed Indicator for Fed Policy
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve has used the unemployment rate to indicate whether monetary policy should be tightened, but at least one economist argues that unemployment alone doesn’t tell the whole story.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve has used the unemployment rate to indicate whether monetary policy should be tightened, but at least one economist argues that unemployment alone doesn’t tell the whole story.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States job market has been improving. But is it close to being good?

articles.headline: Government’s Threat of Daily Fine for Yahoo Shows Aggressive Push for Data
articles.snippet: Court documents shed light on Yahoo’s unsuccessful challenge of federal requests for warrantless surveillance of its foreign users.
articles.abstract: Court documents shed light on Yahoo’s unsuccessful challenge of federal requests for warrantless surveillance of its foreign users.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government was so determined to collect the Internet communications of foreign Yahoo customers in 2008 that it threatened the company with fines of $250,000 a day if it did not immediately comply with a secret court order to turn over the data.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: With Gas Cut Off, Ukraine Looks West
articles.snippet: Ukraine, which receives more than half of its supply from Russia, is looking to reduce its need amid a price dispute and military action with Russian separatists.
articles.abstract: Ukraine, which receives more than half of its supply from Russia, is looking to reduce its need amid a price dispute and military action with Russian separatists.
articles.lead_paragraph: UZHGOROD, Ukraine — Keeping Ukraine warm keeps Andriy Kobolev up at night.

articles.headline: If Scotland Goes, Bankers Fear Britain Could Exit European Union
articles.snippet: As Scotland prepares to vote on independence on Thursday, British bankers worry about an exit from the European Union.
articles.abstract: As Scotland prepares to vote on independence on Thursday, British bankers worry about an exit from the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tremors over a possible breakup of the United Kingdom have been felt here in recent days, as markets gyrate and banks make contingency plans.

articles.headline: Banks Did It Apple’s Way in Payments by Mobile
articles.snippet: The eagerness of banks and card companies to work with Apple on its mobile payment system suggests Apple’s clout and the concern financial players have for their future.
articles.abstract: The eagerness of banks and card companies to work with Apple on its mobile payment system suggests Apple’s clout and the concern financial players have for their future.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s chief financial officer, Marianne Lake, took the stage at a financial conference on Tuesday under strict orders not to mention her company’s involvement in Apple’s new payment system.

articles.headline: U.S. Pins Hope on Syrian Rebels With Loyalties All Over the Map
articles.snippet: President Obama’s determination to train moderate rebels in the battle against ISIS leaves the U.S. dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s determination to train moderate rebels in the battle against ISIS leaves the U.S. dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Obama’s determination to train Syrian rebels to serve as ground troops against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria leaves the United States dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting, with no shared leadership and with hard-line Islamists as its most effective fighters.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Arabs Give Tepid Support to U.S. Fight Against ISIS
articles.snippet: Three years after the United States left Iraq, its return to the region is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with allies finding ways to avoid specific commitments to an expanded effort against Sunni extremists.
articles.abstract: Three years after the United States left Iraq, its return to the region is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with allies finding ways to avoid specific commitments to an expanded effort against Sunni extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Many Arab governments grumbled quietly in 2011 as the United States left Iraq, fearful it might fall deeper into chaos or Iranian influence. Now, the United States is back and getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with leading allies like Egypt, Jordan and Turkey all finding ways on Thursday to avoid specific commitments to President Obama’s expanded military campaign against Sunni extremists.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Air Bag Flaw, Long Known to Honda and Takata, Led to Recalls
articles.snippet: Honda and the air bag maker Takata did not disclose the dangers of exploding air bags for years, despite red flags, opting to settle confidential claims but not issue recalls.
articles.abstract: Honda and the air bag maker Takata did not disclose the dangers of exploding air bags for years, despite red flags, opting to settle confidential claims but not issue recalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: An air bag exploded in a Honda Accord in 2004 in Alabama, shooting out metal fragments and injuring the car’s driver. At a loss to explain the incident, Honda and its Japanese air bag supplier deemed it “an anomaly” and did not issue a recall or seek the involvement of federal safety regulators.

articles.headline: Referendum in Scotland, Dissected by Investor
articles.snippet: The foundation of Sir Tom Hunter, who built a fortune in athletic footwear, published a book dedicated to the independence referendum in Scotland.
articles.abstract: The foundation of Sir Tom Hunter, who built a fortune in athletic footwear, published a book dedicated to the independence referendum in Scotland.
articles.lead_paragraph: Growing up with the name James Stewart, I never thought of Scotland as anything but independent.

articles.headline: Let Us Help You, Hedge Funds Tell Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: Hedge fund firms and investors have bought about 10 percent of the bonds of a beleaguered Puerto Rico, expecting a big return on their investment.
articles.abstract: Hedge fund firms and investors have bought about 10 percent of the bonds of a beleaguered Puerto Rico, expecting a big return on their investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forget, just for a moment, depictions of sharp-elbowed hedge funds, seizing Navy ships from deadbeat nations or pushing for federal investigations into the companies they are betting against.
